"Nuclear war is good because it ends life, which is suffering" punched me in the throat. The first time I heard it, my words tangled in my mouth, caught behind my teeth. I had no response.

Over time, I learned to roll with the hits. It sounds like it crawled out from deep inside an irony poisoned 4chan thread, but it is actually a serious argument for serious people.

Welcome to anti-natalism, where life is so awful that it is better never to be born. A theory used to defend nuclear war. A fringe idea for fringe nerds, like me—a former policy debater. To my suicidal teenage self, the idea that it was cruel to bring life into the world felt oddly comforting. It affirmed the death I felt inside.

Today, it is a cold comfort at best. For the first time in 31 years, I am entertaining switching sides, just like I did in debate.

I am considering becoming someone's mother. How terrifying.

My early twenties were terrible, especially in romance. Partly because I was a mess, partly because I was recovering from being an argumentative asshole, and partly because every relationship was a nonstarter after I dropped the childfree bomb. Even the women I dated wanted kids. Just my luck; all the queers are heteronormative. Where are the 44% of people who don’t want children? I was ready to give up and take it a step further as a single, childless AND cat-free lady. 

Then in my late twenties, I randomly, _finally_ met a man who didn’t want kids. But between the two of us, I was the one truly childfree. My shitty, stressful childhood gifted me with an autoimmune disease, making pregnancies higher risk. And the silence of my biological clock lingers—an absence I can’t escape. 

My now ex was reluctantly childfree. For reasons I won’t get into publicly, he recently changed his mind. Now he wants a gaggle of sweet kids running about a midcentury house. I should have seen it coming. After all, I chose the human version of switch-side debate. “Whiplash” is his name on my phone. My whip smart sweetheart gave me whiplash once again. 

But maybe, just maybe, I’m the one who will whip around this time. Love could be the activation energy that moves my mind. 

I poured that new vigor into a strange new world. Despite being childfree, I had not actively engaged with childfree content before. So I dove deep into online childfree communities, listened to podcasts like _DINKY_ , and read _Regretting Motherhood_ by Orna Donath.

On the flip side, I asked friends for their parenting stories, learned how children learn, attended my first baby shower, and made crafts with millennial mothers. 

Baby shower block painting party! I made (K)isses and (L)ove for little James, due late November

In short, I did what I do best: ignored my emotions, disappeared into my head, and gathered evidence for the greatest debate round of my life. _Resolved: I should have children because I will enjoy motherhood_. Easy enough. I negate the resolution: stay childfree because I will regret motherhood but won’t regret non-motherhood.

But the evidence was sparse. I could easily find regretful parenting stories, no problem. But do people who choose NOT to have kids regret it? As taboo as it is to regret parenthood, it seems even more taboo to say you chose to be childfree and then regretted it decades later. My generation is also likely the first where foregoing children became a widespread, real choice — the data simply isn’t there yet. 

Without good data and studies, I tried another strategy. I negate the resolution: having children is selfish, horrible for the environment, and destructive in a hundred ways.

 _A sure win_ , I thought. All the evidence is in childfree communities. My people.

But I found myself grimacing. Turns out that David Benatar, father of anti-natalism, is practically a household name with 225,000 devotees. Not such a fringe idea after all. And with 1.5 million subscribers, the main childfree forum fared no better. I like children, so the nasty language used to describe them stunned me: _crotch goblins_ and _parasites_ and _spawn_. 

At baseline, it made more sense to view having children as a neutral stance. People must reproduce to continue existing. It is neither good nor bad. It just is. 

As I slowly recover from “objecting to having been born,” I have grown sentimental towards sentient life, this strange fickle thing perhaps only we have in the universe. I’m more persuaded that we should continue our species rather than end it. Expecting the next generation to solve bigger and tougher problems, including ones we likely caused ourselves (like climate change), might be unfair. But that’s evolution, baby. 

I couldn’t convince myself of the usual childfree critiques. Back to the drawing board then. I negate the resolution: stay childfree and enjoy my life.

What better model than the lives of famous and wealthy childfree women? I made a small list: Anna Kendrick, Katharine Hepburn, Helen Mirren, Winona Ryder, Oprah Winfrey, Stevie Nicks, Dolly Parton, Chelsea Handler, Sarah Paulson, Ellen DeGeneres.

Like me, Stevie Nicks hails from Phoenix, Arizona. According to her, if she’d had children, Fleetwood Mac never would have happened. Motherhood was not her destiny.

“Maybe my particular mission was to write songs to make moms and wives feel better.” 

Stevie Nicks 

Well, I’m not goddamn Stevie Nicks. I don’t have a talent meant for billions to enjoy. I’m not even a girl boss who would resent giving up traveling. My best accomplishment so far is not killing myself. I never thought I’d make it past 30, yet I emerged from the black pit, victorious. But I’m entirely empty of dreams. So what _exactly_ am I giving up if I had children? 

Content like Chelsea Handler’s gave me no comfort either. I wondered if women like her were truly happy, because happy people don’t feel the need to rub their happiness in everyone’s faces. I concluded that I just can’t relate to most childfree women. 

A small suspicion sprang to mind, this time directed at the childfree stance: 

**Why identify so strongly with the lack of something?**

One interpretation: parenthood is a community that people opt into, while non-parents are left out for the crime of staying the same. So maybe this godless religion is a way to feel less alone.

I asked myself why I didn’t feel alone, having never felt the need to participate in these communities. 

And there it was. The key, waiting. I’d been searching for answers outside myself, dissecting the logic, avoiding what lies within. But now, I’ve finally reached the door to my emotions. I had been too intellectual about this, debating myself in circles. 

So I forfeit the debate. Leave my head, follow my heart. 

I need to feel this. 

I turn the key and step inside. 

I know why I don’t identify with the lack of something. 

I know why I can’t proselytize like others do. 

I’ve never been scared of being alone. I’ve always felt like there was an invisible wall separating me from others. I can press my fingers against the glass, and the few who reach back meet my fingers with their own. But I can’t feel the warmth of that phantom touch. 

It’s okay for me. I’m used to it, feeling not-quite-human. 

But there’s no way I want that feeling for my children. I want them to be happy, secure, playful. 

I’m scared that I can’t give that to them, when I can’t even give that to myself. 

I close my eyes, and I remember Sophia.

Sophia, Sophia. My broken mirror, Sophia. 

Of all the stories I’ve come across, hers is the one that truly haunts me. She shares a background marked by violence, much like mine. 

But she always dreamed of having children. She believed that giving her kids everything she didn’t have, granting them the childhood she’d always longed for, would be her path to healing. She thought nothing could be more meaningful. 

After having two children, she realizes that her belief is “total bullshit.” 

_Why is it bullshit_? I want to scream. _TELL ME, SOPHIA!_ I comb through her story desperately, searching for her reasoning. 

But Sophia is silent. She never explains why. 

I plunge into cold despair. 

The nightmare is so clear. Flickering scenes flash between past and present, present and future, beauty and agony. I can see my little darling, my life, my only. I lie on the bed most of the day, nearly comatose. Just like how I was in college. 

“Why is Mommy so sad all the time?” my child whispers to their father. I see him shake his head, now completely gray, each strand a testament to sorrow. Slowly, then all at once, my child inherits my darkness. Their eyes become open wounds, swallowing everything light and pure and good. 

I open my eyes to the sobering daylight. 

I would damn my children to a lifetime of being outsiders, like me. I would pollute them with my lack. I just know I would. I can scarcely bear the thought. 

_But what if I’m wrong_? A tiny voice stirs. I’m wrong all the time. Why wouldn’t I be wrong at the worst time, sinking a great love and an entire world of children and grandchildren and magnificent dreams to the bottom of the sea? 

I’m not one for regrets, I reassure myself. _But this is different_ , the voice insists. I could end up an old woman, staring out the window with only regrets instead of a view. 

The voice rings with truth, but the regrets feel inseparably yoked. 

_Two roads diverged in a wood, and I—_

I regret not having kids with someone I love, or I regret becoming a mother. 

Which regret would I rather have? 

I wish I could say. I wish writing this helped.

I’d been searching for these stories and statistics like they were scattered keys, hoping that the right one would unlock the right door. But I realize now that they will always slip through my fingers. There is no other door. There is only this one old door I already opened, and it leads me into the same empty room. 

I stand there in silence. It’s only me inside, waiting for my answer. 

This decision is mine alone. 

And it has to come from my true self. 

I open my mouth to speak, but the words catch.

I don’t know who I am.
